SafetyInspectionBy: State of WA Dept. of Labor & Industries

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



COLUMBIA COUNTY FARM BUREAU



We are a fertilizer facility.  The only material considered hazardous at this facility is aqua (a 20 wt% solution of ammonia in water).  



Our facility has three atmospheric-pressure 30,000 gallon tanks for storing aqua, equipment for receiving aqua by truck and equipment for transferring aqua from storage to trucks for delivery to customers.  



It is our policy to meet, or exceed, all local, state, and national standards relating to handling aqua.  This includes diking our storage facility to contain any spills and thereby prevent soil and water contamination and minimize ammonia release from any spills.  Site-specific Safety Information is tabulated below.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



Facility:   Columbia County Farm Bureau



MSDS Aqua (Y, N):  Y



Max. Intended Inventory:    90,000 gal.    686,000 lb.

Tanks: Three (3) for Aqua

Capacity (Gallons):    30,000

Dimensions:    11.5 dia. x 36' high

MAWP @ Temp.:    Atmospheric



Vent (Y, N):    Y



Level Indicator (Y, N)/ type:    Y/ Slight Gauge



Pump/ Compressor:    Use P= Pump, C= Compressor

Manufacturer/ Model:    P/ Berkley B2-1/2T    PMS - 5-3/8" impeller



Diked Area:    



Dimensions:    74' x 38' approx.



A Hazard Analysis was performed.  Results are tabulated below.



HAZARD ANALYSIS FOR AQUA STORAGE FACILITIES



GENERAL



What if?:            Fire occurs at or around storage facility?

Consequences:        Potential to overheat and overpressure storage tanks, potential tank damage an/or release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Grass, brush, flammables kept a minimum of 10 feet from storage tanks.  Vents on storage tank protect against overpressure.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Flood occurs at storage facility?

Consequences:        Potential to lift and damage tanks and/or lines, potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Tanks are anchored; area is diked to prevent spreading of spill and to minimize rate of evaporation.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What i

f?:            Storage facility is hit by tornado?

Consequences:        Potential to lift and damage tank and/or lines, potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Tanks are anchored; area is diked to prevent spreading of spill and to minimize rate of evaporation.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Facility is hit by lightning?

Consequences:        Potential to damage tank, piping, or equipment.  Potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Storage area is diked to prevent spreading of spill and to minimize rate of evaporation.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What If?:            There is a power outage?

Consequences:        Potentially unable to load or unload.  No safety consequences.

Safeguards:        

Recommendations:    



What if?:            Vehicle impacts facility?

Consequences:        Potential to damage tank, piping, or equipment.  Potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Vehicle impact is prevented by diking.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



TRANSPORT



What if?:            Transport contains something other than aqua?

Consequences:        Potential to contaminate aqua storage, potential to overheat and damage tank from heat of reaction.

Safeguards:        Agreement with supplier to only supply aqua.  Atmospheric vent protects against overpressure.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Transport rolls during loading/unloading?

Consequences:        Potential to beak lines to storage tanks, potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Area is diked to prevent spreading of a spill and to minimize rate of evaporation.  Excess flow varies on transport.  Driver chocks wheels and sets brake prior to connecting hoses.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Transport leaves before disconnecting hosing?

Consequecnes:        Potential to break lines to storage tanks, potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Area is diked to prevent spreading of spill and to minimize rate of evaporation.  Excess flow valves on transport.  Driver chocks wheels and sets brake prior to connec

ting hoses. 

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Transport level gauge malfunctions?

Consequences:        Potential to overfill storage tank, potential to overpressure and damage storage tank, potential to release ammonia.

Safeguards:        Driver present during the filling procedure, level gauge on the storage tank, atmospheric vent on storage tank prevents overexposure and damage. 

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



HOSES/CONNECTIONS



What if?:            Liquid transfer hose valve leaks?

Consequences:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.

Safeguards:        Tank area is diked to contain spills and minimize rate of evaporation.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.

Recommendations:    Consider installing water tub or safety shower at site.  Ensure full-face gas mask for each person at site during operations.



What if?:            Liquid hose disconnected before transport/truck liquid valve shut?

Consequences:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.

Safeguards:        Hose transport valves located at disconnect point of transfer hose to facilitate quick valve closing and minimize release.  Operator trained to check valves.  Excess flow valve on transport.  

Recommendations:    Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.  See HOSES/CONNECTIONS, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.



What if?:            Liquid hose disconnected before facility liquid transfer valve shut?

Consequences:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.

Safeguards:        Tank area is diked to contain spills and minimize rate of evaporation.  Operator trained to check valves, operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.

Recommendations:    See HOSES/CONNECTIONS, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.



What if?:            Liquid hose ruptures?

Consequences:        Potential ammonia release.  Potential personnel exposure.

Safeguards:        Excess flow valve on transport.  Hose and transport valves located at dis

connect point of transfer hose to facilitate quick valve closing.  Tank area is diked to contain spills and minimized rate of evaporation.  Operator wears protective gloves and safety goggles, ammonia odor.

Recommendations:    See HOSES/CONNECTIONS, liquid transfer hose valve leaks.



PUMP/COMPRESSOR



What if?:            Pump seal leaks?

Consequences:        Potential ammonia release.  

Safeguards:        Block valve located on suction and discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump operation. 

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Pump suction plugged?

Consequences:        Potential to damage pump, potential seal leak, potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Block valves located on suction and discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump operation.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Pump discharge plugged?

Consequences:        Potential to damage pump, potential seal leak, potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Block valves located on suction on discharge of pump to isolate leak.  Operator present during pump operation.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



AQUA STORAGE TANKS



What if?:            Storage tank overfilled?

Consequences:        Potential to overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty before filling and tank capacity greater than transport capacity.  Atmospheric vent on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.  Tank area is diked to contain spills and minimize rate of evaporation.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Liquid line to storage tank blocked in liquid full?

Consequences:        Potential to overpressure and damage line/hose, potential to release ammonia. 

Safeguards:        Hydrostatic relief valves installed in lines with potential to be blocked in liquid full, excess flow valves in lines on storage tank.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Storage tank level

gauge malfunctions?

Consequences:        Potential to overfill storage tank, potential overpressure and/or damage storage tank, potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Driver present during filling procedure, tank nearly empty when filled and tank volume is greater than transport volume.  Atmospheric vent on storage tank to prevent overpressure and damage.  Tank area is diked to contain spills and minimize rate of evaporation.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



What if?:            Storage tank has excess corrosion/erosion?

Consequences:        Potential for storage tank to crack, rupture or leak, potential release of ammonia.

Safeguards:        Storage tank is well maintained, painted and routinely visually inspected.

Recommendations:    Safeguards adequate.



To further ensure safe operations of the facility, our employees are trained in procedures for sage handling of hazardous materials, and in safe operating and maintenance procedures.



Operation procedures are as follows:



OPERATING PROCEDURES



AQUA LOADING FROM BULK STORAGE



WARNING:         Aqua can be very harmful if inhaled.

                          Aqua can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns. 

                  ALWAYS wear filter mask or splash goggles when working on aqua lines.

                  ALWAYS wear rubber/Neoprene safety gloves when working on aqua lines.

        ALWAYS vent line away from you.



CAUTION:     Never leave transfer operation unattended.

                          If necessary to leave area, find a qualified person to attend the operation, or 

        stop the operation.



1) Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.

2) Get paper work and information about what tank to load from.

3) Determine last load in truck, and have truck washed out if necessary.

4) Ensure truck is placarded for aqua.

5) Spot the truck in loading area.

6) Ensure truck is chocked.

7) Ensure that truck vent is open.

8) Remove nozzle cap on truck nozzle.



If necessary, clean connector with a ra

g and replace worn or damaged gaskets or O-rings.



9) Connect hose.



CAUTION:     Never drag a hose connector or valve across the ground.

                        Never carry a valve by the handwheel or operating lever.



        Always carry by the valve body, with the outlet pointed way from your body.



AQUA LOADING FROM BULK STORAGE (Continued)



10) Ensure that valve on storage tank is open.

11) Ensure that pump suction and discharge valves are open.

12) Open hose valve.

13) Open valve on truck

14) Start pump.



WARNING:    If a leak or fire occurs, stop pump immediately.

                             Leak:     If possible, stop leak.  If not possible, STOP OPERATION.

                             Fire:       If possible, extinguish with fire extinguisher.  If not possible 

            CONACT FIRE DEPARTMENT.



15) When filling level is reached, stop pump.

16) Close valve on storage tank.

17) Close valve on truck.

18) Close truck vent valve.

19) Close hose valve.

20) Place drip bucket under hose and either:

    A) Crack connection to release pressure, or

    B) Open bleeder valve to release pressure.

21) Disconnect and store hose.

22) Replace cap on truck hose nozzle.

23) Take copies of completed paper work to operations manager's office.



MAINTENANCE POLICY



1. Employees performing maintenance are trained to safely maintain storage tanks and equipment, and are certified as required by the Training Policy.

2. Maintenance contractors are required to certify that their employees are qualified to perform job tasks in a safe manner.

3. Equipment is inspected during normal operations and deficiencies are reported to the shop foreman.  The facility is inspected periodically by the state Department of Ecology.  Inspection reports are on file in the company office.

4. Maintenance procedures follow.



REMOVE/REPLACE PUMP OR COMPRESSOR



Remove Pump/Compressor:



WARNING:    Aqua can be very harmful if inhaled.

        Aqua can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.

Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.

        Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.

        Always vent line away from you.



WARNING:     Before removing/replacing a pump or compressor, ensure that the line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.



1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.

2. Ensure line segment which includes pump/compressor is protected from any energy source (i.e. pump/compressor block valves are closed and locked).

3. Ensure breaker for pump/compressor is in off position, tagged, and locked to prevent anyone from inadvertently switching breaker on.

4. Disconnect electrical wiring from pump/compressor.

5. If there is a vent valve in the line segment, open valve and allow line to vent.  (If there is no vent valve in the line segment, the line segment may be vented from the flanges on the suction and discharge side of the pump/compressor flange as described in Step 6.)

6. Loosen the flange bolts on the side of flange opposite from you (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, but only far enough to start the line segment venting. 



CAUTION:    If the line does not stop venting, make sure no other lines are venting into the     line segment.  If other lines are not venting to the line segment, a block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank may need to be emptied before removing the pump/compressor.



7. Continue by loosening all flange bolts.

8. Spread flanges to relieve any residual pressure.

9. Remove bolts, separate flanges, and remove gaskets.

10. Remove coupling or drive belt.

11. Loosen base mount bolts.

12. Remove pump/compressor.  If necessary use hoist or crane to prevent injury when removing pump/compressor.



Replace Pump/Compressor:



1.  Inspect pump/compressor flanges for scratches or defects.    



NOTE:         Do not reinstall pump/compressor with badly scratched or galled flanges.



2. Clean flanges if necessary.

3. Ensur

e bolts are proper grade and length.

4. Apply anti-seize compound to bolts.

5. Place pump/compressor back on base mounts.  Use rigged hoist/crane if necessary.  Tighten base mount bolts in start pattern two or three time to ensure a solid foundation.

6. Insert flange bolts and new gaskets.

7. Tighten flange bolts in cross pattern.

8. Repeat tightening pattern to ensure that all bolts are tight.  (If tightening pattern not repeated, seals may be inadequate and may leak.)

9. Alight and replace coupling or drive belt.

10. Reconnect electrical wiring to pump/compressor.

11. Return pump/compressor breaker to the 'ON' position and test the pump/compressor to ensure the wiring was reconnected correctly.

12. Open block valves and allow line to pressure with aqua and check for leaks.

13. Clean and store tools.



REMOVE/REPLACE FLANGED VALVE



WARNING:    Aqua can be very harmful if inhaled.

        Aqua can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.



        Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.

        Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.

        Always vent line away from you.



Remove Valve:



WARNING:     Before removing/replacing a pump or compressor, ensure that the line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.



WARNING:         If valve is on storage tank, ensure that tank is empty.



1. Ensure line segment, which includes valve, is protected from any energy source.  (i.e. block valve is closed and locked between valve and storage tank).

2. If there is a valve to vent the line, open valve and allow line to vent.

3. If there is NO valve to vent the line,  the line segment may be vented from the valve as described in Step 4.

4. Loosen the flange bolts on the opposite side of flange (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, only far enough to start the line segment venting.



If the line does not stop venting, check to make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If there are no other

lines, the block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank must be emptied before removing the pump/compressor.



5. Begin removing valve by loosening bolts on the opposite side of flanges (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).



CAUTION:    If line not adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 3.



6. Continue by loosening all flange bolts.  If necessary, rig hoist/jack to support valve.

7. Spread flanges to relieve any residual pressure.

8. Remove bolts, separate flanges, and remove gaskets.

9. Remove valve.



Replace Valve:



1. Inspect valve flanges for scratches or defects.



NOTE:         Do not reinstall valve with badly scratched or galled flanges.



2. Clean flanges if necessary.

3. Ensure bolts are proper grade and length.

4. Apply anti-seize compound to bolts.

5. Place valve in position and make sure valve is oriented so that pipeline flow is in the same direction as the arrow on the valve.  Use a rigged hoist/jack if necessary.

6. Insert bolts and new gaskets.

7. Tighten bolts in a cross pattern.

8. Repeat tightening pattern to ensure that all bolts are tight.  (If tightening pattern not repeated, seals may be inadequate and may leak.)

9. Open block valve and allow line to pressure with aqua and check for leaks.

10. Clean and store tools.



REMOVE/REPLACE FLANGE GASKET



WARNING:    Aqua can be very harmful in inhaled.

        Aqua can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.



        Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.

        Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.

        Always vent line away from you.



Remove Gasket:



WARNING:    Before removing/replacing gasket, ensure that line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.



WARNING:    If flange is on storage tank, ensure that tank is empty.



1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.

2. Ensure line segment, which includes gasket is isolated from any energy source. (i.e. block valves are closed and locked and

pump motor breaker is locked off).

3. If there is a vent valve in the line segment, open valve and allow line to vent.  (If there is no vent valve in the line segment, the line segment may be vented from the gasketed flange as described in Step 4.)

4. Loosen the flange bolts on the side of flange opposite from you (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, but only far enough to start the line segment venting. 



If the line does not stop venting, make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If other lines are not venting to the line segment, a block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank may need to be emptied before removing the pump/compressor.



5. Begin by removing gasket by loosening bolts on opposite side of flanges (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).

6. Continue by loosening all flange bolts



CAUTION:    If line not adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 3.



7. Spread flanges to relieve any residual pressure.

8. Remove bolts, separate flanges, and remove gaskets.



Replace Gasket:



1. Inspect gasket and flanges for scratches or defects.



NOTE:    Do not reinstall gasket with any defects.



2. Clean flanges if necessary.

3. Ensure bolts are proper grade and length.

4. Apply anti-seize compound to bolts.

5. Insert two bolts and slide new gasket into position.

6. Insert remaining bolts and tighten in a cross pattern.

7. Repeat tightening pattern to ensure that all bolts are tight.  (If tightening pattern not repeated, seals may be inadequate and may leak.)

8. Open block valve, and allow line to pressure with aqua and check for leaks.

9. Clean and store tools.



REMOVE/REPLACE THREADED VALVE



WARNING:    Aqua can be very harmful if inhaled.

        Aqua can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.



        Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.

        Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.

        Always vent line a

way from you.



WARNING:    If valve is one storage tank, ensure that tank is empty.



Remove Valve:



WARNING:    Before removing/replacing valve, ensure that the line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.



1. Ensure line segment which includes valve is protected from any energy source.   (i.e. block valve is closed and locked between valve and storage tank).

2. If there is a valve to vent the line, open valve and allow line to vent.

3. If there is NO valve to vent the line, the line segment may be vented from the valve as described in Step 4.

4. Loosen the valve packing only until the aqua begins to vent from the line segment.  When the venting has stopped, carefully loosen the packing to ensure the line segment has fully vented.



If the line does not stop venting, check to make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If there are no other lines the block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank must be emptied before removing the pump/compressor.



5. Begin removing valve by loosening union or valve thread.



CAUTION:    If line not adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 3.



6. Continue by loosening until valve is free.  If necessary, rig hoist/jack to support valve.

7. Remove valve.



Replace Valve:



1. Clean valve threads with cleaning solvent approved by aqua.



Take care to prevent solvent contacting internal valve parts



2. Clean line threads with cleaning solvent approved by aqua.

3. Apply thread sealing compound to male threads.



Ensure that compound is approved for aqua service by checking container label.



4. Carefully screw threaded valve onto line.



Avoid cross threading.  After screwing in hand tight, tighten with open end or adjustable wrench.  Do not tighten valve more than 1/2 turn with wrench.



5. Open block valve and allow line to pressure with aqua and check for leaks.

6. Clean and store tools



REMOVE/REPLACE HYDROSTATIC RELIEF VALVE



WARNING:    Aqua can be very harmful if inhal

ed.

        Aqua can cause eye, skin, and respiratory tract burns.

        Always wear splash goggles when working on aqua lines.

        Wear rubber/neoprene safety gloves.

        Always vent line away from you.



Remove Hydrostatic Relief Valve:



WARNING:    Before removing/replacing hydrostatic relief valve, ensure that the line segment is vented to atmospheric pressure.



1. Ensure that gas masks and protective clothing are readily available.

2. Ensure line segment which includes hydrostatic valve is isolated from any energy source (i.e. block valves are closed and locked, and pump motor breaker is locked off).

3. If there is a valve to vent the line, open valve and allow line to vent.  (If there is NO valve to vent the line, the line segment may be vented from a gasketed flange as described in Step 4.)

4. Loosen the flange bolts on the side of flange opposite from you (to direct any spray, from residual contents in line, away from you).  Gently pry the flange apart, but only far enough to start the line segment venting.



If the line does not stop venting, check to make sure no other lines are venting into the line segment.  If there are no other lines, the block valve must be leaking and the bulk storage tank must be emptied before removing the relief valve.



5. After venting the line segment, the hydrostatic relief valve may be removed by unscrewing it from the line.  A channel lock or pliers may be needed.



CAUTION:    If line not adequately cleaned or purged, STOP, and return to step 3.



Replace Hydrostatic Relief Valve:



1. Inspect new hydrostatic relief valve for debris or defects.



NOTE:        Do not reinstall hydrostatic relief valve after removing from the line.



2. Clean valve threads with cleaning solvent approved by aqua.



Take care to prevent solvent contacting internal valve parts



3. Clean line threads with cleaning solvent approved by aqua.

4. Apply thread sealing compound to male threads.



Ensure that compound is approved for aqua service by check

ing container label.



5. Carefully screw threaded valve onto line.



Avoid cross threading.  After screwing in hand tight, tighten with open end or adjustable wrench.  Do not tighten valve more than 1/2 turn with wrench.



6.   Open block valve and allow line to pressure with aqua and check for leaks.

7. Clean and store tools



EMPLOYEE TRAINING POLICY



This company training policy complies with state and U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) rules governing training.



All persons operating ammonia/aqua processes are certified as having the knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely perform duties and responsibilities associated with ammonia/aqua processes.  Training certifications are on record in the company office.



Refresher skills training is provided at least triennially.  Initial and refresher HAZMAT training are provided for persons involved with ammonia/aqua operations.  Employees are trained in major process changes before operating the changed process.



We have also coordinated with the Columbia County and Dayton Volunteer Fire Departments to repsond in the unlikely even of an emergency.  Our Emergency Repsonse Policy is described below.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY



1. Emergencies are handled by onsite personnel according to the Emergency Shutdown procedure on the following page.

2. Personnel stop leaks or extinguish fires if they can easily control the situation.

3. For more severe situations, it is company policy to contact the local fire department and assist as directed by the fire department.



EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN



WARNING:    Aqua can be very harmful if inhaled.

        Aqua can cause eye, skin and respiratory tract burns.



        Never enter vapor area without respiratory protection, protective gloves, boots, and suit.



All MSDA for aqua is posted at the facility.  For first aid/emergency health care, colsult MSDS.



1. Warn everyone at facility.

2. If possible, shut down and operating pump or compressor by pushing remote stop butto

n on the start/stop panel or by switching off the breaker.

3. Notify the fire department (911).



Give your location as:    Columbia County Farm Bureau

            108 N. Pine



4. Evacuate persons not required for emergency action and help limit access to the area.  (Evacuate to upwind, or crosswind, location.)

5. If entering affected area.

    A) Put on respiratory protection

    B) Put on gloves, suits, and boots before entering affected area.

    C) If possible, isolate leak by closing appropriate valves.

6. After the emergency has been resolved, an Incident Investigation form must be filled out and kept on file.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION POLICY



1. Incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release are investigated within 48 hours.

2. A report of the investigation is prepared using the Incident Investigation for that follows.  The report is kept on file in the company office for five years.

3. Findings and recommendations from the investigation are promptly addressed.

4. Resolutions and corrective actions are documented on the investigation form.

5. Findings and corrective actions are reviewed with all personnel whose job tasks are affected.
